author.orgName: African American History, Culture, and Digital Humanities (AADHum)

respStmt.orgName: Maryland Institute for Technology in the Humanities (MITH)

respStmt.resp: Student newspapers archived and provided by
respStmt.orgName: University Archives University of Maryland College Park Maryland

extent.measure: 2 partial pages of original source material

publisher.orgName: African American History, Culture, and Digital Humanities (AADHum)

seriesStmt.title: Machine-Readable Texts for the Study of Freedom in UMD Student Newspaper Coverage of African American Life

bibl.title: Reckoning with Freedom: Legacies of Exclusion, Dehumanization, and Black Resistance in the Rhetoric of the Freedmen's Bureau

editorialDecl.p: All typographical errors have been preserved. When possible, suggested corrections are provided.
Structural formatting has been partially preserved. Page jumps and paragraphs have been retained, along with most line breaks. However, column breaks have not.

hyphenation.p: All end-of-line hyphenation has been regularized.

projectDesc.p: This project aims to provide students, scholars, and practitioners with a basic introduction to the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI), in the hopes that XML training will help foster critical scholarship at the intersections of African American history, culture, and digital humanities. This free training has been provided as part of the 2017-2018AADHum series of digital humanities incubators.

org.orgName: University of Maryland, School of Law
University of Maryland, School of Pharmacy
University of Maryland, School of Dentistry
University of Maryland, School of Nursing

org.note: Renamed as Morgan State University in 1975.
Frequently referred to by its location, Princess Anne.

persName.roleName: University President, University of Maryland, College Park

personGrp.note: This person group is necessary for the reading and interpretation of this text, as this text often uses "the negro" to generalize about all black and African Americans.

personGrp.persName: University System of Maryland (U.S.M.) Board of Regents
personGrp.note: The Board of Regents is comprised of 17 members, including 1 full-time student. Appointed by the Governor of Maryland, the Board oversees the university system's academic, administrative, and financial operations.

revisionDesc.change: No changes have been made at this time.

div.p:
This is the first part in a series tracing
the history of the Negro at the University.

The history of the Negro at the Univer- sityUniversity
unfolds with awesome slowness. It
evolves over a 20-year period in which
court suits, financial strains and public
opinion gradually open the campus gates
to black Americans.

The first Negro to attend the University
was Donald Gaines Murray. A graduate
of Amherst, Murray applied to the Uni- versityUniversity
Law School in 1935. By 1936 he
was accepted. The year’s delay in Mur- ray’sMurray's
acceptance was due to a detour his
application took —a detour through the
state Attorney General’s office and the
Circuit Court of Appeals.

In 1935, Murray was initially refused
admission to the University but offered
a scholarship to Howard University in
Washington, D.C., if he were accepted
there. Murray declined the scholarship
offer, and instead sued the Board of Re- gentsBoard of Regents
for denying him admission “be- causebecause of his color."

In court, the University conceded that
Murray was denied admission because of
his race. Education in the state had fol- lowedfollowed
a separate but equal, bi-racialbiracial
policy. Provisions for members of the
Negro race to be sent by scholarship to
professional schools outside the state
were made. The University President
H. C. Byrd further added that a “finan- cialfinancial
risk" would be involved in accepting
Negroes, for if Negroes were admitted
to the state university, it was projected
that many students would withdraw.

Defendant Murray, however, contended
that a law education received at Howard
would not be equal nor comparable to a
law education gained at the University.
Murray intended to practice law in Bal- timore CityBaltimore City,
and the University legal
curriculum included special courses in
Maryland law. If he attended Howard,
Murray felt he would be at a disadvan- tagedisadvantage
when competing in a Baltimore
court with white lawyers schooled in the
state.

On the grounds that Murray had been
denied admission to the University due
only to the color of his skin, a violation
of the Fourteenth Amendment was de- clareddeclared
by the Court. Murray was ad- mittedadmitted
to the University's Law School in
fall, 1936.

Murray’s bold and successful court
fight signalled the start of other Negro
advances to the gates of the University.
The law school began receiving—and
accepting—other Negro applications, and
by 1939 there were three Negroes at- tendingattending
law classes in Baltimore.

Although the law school now had an
integrated admissions policy, for the next
15 years all other branches of the Uni- versityUniversity
remained segregated. In 1946 and
again in 1949, the School of Pharmacy
denied admission to Negro applicants.
Several Negroes applying to under
graduateundergraduate
classes in College Park were
also refused enrollment.

The University’s admissions policy
was clearly bi-racial: Negro profes- sionalprofessional
and graduate students were re- ferredreferred
to out-of-state Institutions on
scholarship; and undergraduate ap- plicantsapplicants
were rejected and steered to-
wardtoward
Morgan State and Princess Anne
Colleges.

Morgan and Princess Anne were two
state-owned Negro institutions. Morgan
operates apart from the University.
Princess AnnPrincess Anne was incorporated into the
University in 1935 to comply with a sec- tionsection
on Negro education in the Land Grant
College. (The Morrill Act.)

This statute required that a share of
land-grant allocations go to Negroes.
By both annexing and recognizing Prin- cess AnnePrincess Anne
as a land-grant college for
colored students, the University could
continue to receive Federal funds granted
under the act.

With Princess Anne a part of the Uni- versityUniversity,
a special fiscal policy was de- viseddevised
for the Eastern Shore college.
Money was to be distributed proportion- atelyproportionately,
on the basis of state population,
between the white and Negro branches of
the school. Initially, $210,000 was poured
into Princess Anne. Over the next decade
however, the Negro institution was more
or less ignored.

In 1947 an investigation of Princess
Anne was released by the Marbury Com- missionCommission.
In its final report, the Com- missionCommission
described the institution as a
"Jim-Crow school." Plumbing was de- ficientdeficient,
dormitories inadequate and many
buildings were of “indefinite origin."
Academically, the institution was only a
shadow of a college; it was unaccredited,
its faculty was small, its enrollment had
never surpassed 159 and half of the stu- dentstudent
body came from out of state.

The Commission concluded that Prin- cess AnnePrincess Anne
had proved unsuccessful as a
Negro institution. It was recommended
that Morgan State College, the accredited
Negro school in Baltimore, assume con- trolcontrol
of Princess Anne. Morgan State, the
Commission felt, had greater resources
and its location would attract more Negro
undergraduates than the Somerset County
school had.

This recommendation was received
like a bomb by University President
Byrd. A two-year fight began between
Byrd, the State Legislature and the com- munitycommunity.
Byrd wanted to keep Princess
Anne in his domain. He made sweeping
promises to the Negro populace concern- ingconcerning
the potential of Princess Anne. He
proposed to the legislature a four million
doUar appropriation to rebuild and re- vitalizerevitalize
the Eastern Shore facilities.

At hearings, Byrd’s opponents noted
that the University had incorporated
Princess Anne in 1936 but had “failed
to perform its duty." A Baltimore Sun

editorial called Princess Anne "a
kind of Cinderella to the Univer- sityUniversity."
Byrd's effort to sustain
the institution, stated the Sun,
was an effort to stop "a threat
to part of his domain," not a sin- ceresincere
effort for the welfare of the
Negro community. Furthermore,
Byrd’s move to pour four million
dollars into the college was a
plan to “so deeply" commit the
State "to the development of Prin- cess AnnePrincess Anne,
that there could be no
withdrawal."

Despite oratory, petitions,
hearings and editorials in op- positionopposition
to Byrd, the president’s
wheeling and dealing in Annapo- lisAnnapolis
brought victory to his propos- alproposal.
In 1949 the Legislature appro- priatedappropriated
$300,000 to the Negro
institution, indicating con- fidenceconfidence
in Byrd’s continued
administration of Princess Anne.
With this and subsequent appro- priationsappropriations,
Byrd slowly augmented
Princess Anne's faculty and fa- cilitiesfacilities.

While the Princess Anne issue
was debated, the University's
“separate but equal," bi-racial
philosophy pervaded its dealings.
In 1947, a Negro Air Force
veteran, Major Wilmore B.
Leonard, had registered for
graduate study in College Park.
At first he was “provisionally"
accepted. Later, through, he
was rejected.

Protesting, the veteran was
told that the University was re- jectingrejecting
all students "accepted
provisionally" that year. (Pro- visionalProvisional
status indicated that oth- erother
applicants had better academic
records.) Due to overcrowding
in the school, students accepted
on provisional bases were, at
later dates, all rejected.

Racial issues at the graduate
level lay dormant for some time
after Leonard’s inquiry. The
following summer, however,
found Byrd facing NAACP picket
lines in the newspapers.

In an effort to keep College
Park white, the University was
offering summer courses for
Negro teachers at Douglas High
School in Baltimore. The
NAACP, angered that the Univer- sityUniversity
was equating Douglas’s fa- cilitiesfacilities
with those at College
Park, organized a picket line on
registration day.

Only two students dared to
cross the line drawn by hundreds
of placard-carrying marchers.
The students, both Negro teach- ersteachers,
registered and took summer
courses.

All summer long a verbal bat- tlebattle
was waged between the NAACP
the Afro-American Newspaper
and Byrd. The Afro-American—
which parenthetically noted that
Dr. Byrd’s title referred to an
honorary doctorate degree in
philosophy—maintained that the
Douglas classes were “ludi- crousludicrous."
For two students, the
University was employing three
teachers and one librarian.

Unabashed, Byrd replied by
emphasizing that the State of
Maryland’s education policy was
one of “controlled segregation."

Following the hectic summer
session, the NAACP found itself
defending Martin B. Booth, a
Negro applicant to the Maryland
School of Pharmacy. Booth had
applied to the school in May of
1948 and had been rejected on
the grounds that “the school has
filled its quota." However, on
August 14 of that same year,
Booth reapplied for admission
the next, or any succeeding se- mestersemester.

This time the University re- fusedrefused
to pass on the Negro’s ap- plicationapplication.
Demanding some ac- tionaction,
Booth went to court, claiming
that the original "rejection was
based not on the time of his ap- plicationapplication,
but because of his race
or color."

In newspaper statements, Byrd
responded to Booth’s accusation.
“We haven't turned down anybody
in any school on the basis of his
being a Negro," he said, explain- ingexplaining
that the University refers
Negroes to Negro institutions.

Booth’s case was apparently
lost somewhere on the litigation
ladder. The only further public
record on the matter is a nota- tionnotation
in the Board of Regents
minutes of Sept. 24, 1948. It was
stated that "future actions" on
Booth’s application would be "on
the advice of the (State’s) attorney
general."

The summer of 1949 abounded
in suits brought against the Uni- versityUniversity
by Negro applicants. One
applicant to the School of Phar- macyPharmacy
and two for the School of
Dentistry alleged that race was
the sole reason for their rejec- tionsrejections.
A home economics student
and an engineering undergraduate
were refused admission to under- graduateundergraduate
studies at College Park.

A total of six suits were brought
against the University, and the
Board of Regents replied to them
by stating that the University had
a “general policy of segregation.
Separate but equal facilities”
were provided for Negro appli- cantsapplicants
who were state citizens.

In reply to the court order of
mandamus, the University of- feredoffered
the six Negroes admis- sionadmission
into Morgan State or Prin- cess AnnePrincess Anne,
or scholarships to
out-of-state schools.

Provisions for out-of-state
scholarships were arranged by
the University in conjunction with
the Southern Regional Compact.
This compact was composed of
14 Southern states which pooled
their educational facilities. When
certain programs were lacking in
one state, resources from another
state could be used.

Up until 1949, the Regional
Contracts had been, in total,
awarded to 18 Negroes and 217
whites. The Compact was not
viewed as a means for thwarting
integration.

In 1949, however, local groups
in Maryland charged that the Uni- versityUniversity
'by settling mandamus
suits with out-of-state scholar- shipscholarship
offers' was using the region- alregional
compact to evade equal educa- tioneducation
statutes.

Eighteen year old Esther Mc- CreadyMcCready,
who had applied to the
Maryland School of Nursing, re- fusedrefused
a scholarship to MeHarry
Medical College in Nashville,
Tenn. Miss McCready claimed
that she could not be required to
go out of her state to receive
education available at home. Ask- ingAsking
her to leave the state due to
her race was denying her con- stitutionalconstitutional
rights under the Four- teenthFourteenth
Amendment.

The University, however, felt
it had "discharged its constitu- tionalconstitutional
obligation to afford equal
education opportunities" by of- feringoffering
the applicant a scholarship
to MeHarry. In court it was even
brought out that MeHarry was a
school whose facilities were “su- periorsuperior"
to Maryland’s.

A lower court upheld the con- tentioncontention
of the University. But the
Maryland Circuit Court of Ap- pealsAppeals
reversed this decision.
Miss McCready’s rights had in- deedindeed been denied.

Referring to State of Missouri
ex-rel. Gaines v. Canada, the
Court held that a scholarship to
MeHarry “did not relieve the
state of its responsibility to pro- videprovide
equal opportunities for Ne- groesNegroes
within the boundaries of
the State. By no rational means
could the State extend its boun- dariesboundaries
to Nashville, Tenn."

The Court further held that the
“regional compact cannot be used
to maintain a segregated system
of higher education." Miss Mc- CreadyMcCready’s admission to the Mary- landMaryland
School of Nursing was or- deredordered.

Still fighting for its segregation
policy, the University appealed
this decision to the Supreme
Court. The High Court, however,
denied certiori, and the issue was
settled. Miss McCready became
the first Negro to attend the
Nursing School.

The implications of the case
were clear. The University would
have to make its Negro institu- tionsinstitutions
parallel to its white insti- tutionsinstitutions
or begin admtting Ne- groesNegroes
to College Park and to all
Baltimore professional schools.

Byrd and the Legislature sup- portedsupported
the former alternative,
i.e. a “dual school system" over
an integrated one. For several
years, new programs were in- stitutedinstituted
and more funds were
poured into Princess Anne. How- everHowever,
court litigations were now
travelling at a pace faster than
the State's educational budget.

In 1951 Hiram T. Whittle, a 20
year old Negro who wished to
transfer from Morgan State into
the College Park engineering
program, received a writ of
mandamus admitting him to the
University. The State’s attorney
general advised the Board of Re- gentsRegents
to accept Whittle since
College Park housed the only
state supported engineering fa- cilitiesfacilities
in Maryland.

Whittle thereby set several
precedents. He was the first
Negro admitted to the University
without a court battle—though he
did follow in the wake of the Mc-
CreadyMcCready
storm. He was also the
first Negro to attend classes in
the College Park campus and to
live in a white dormitory.

At this same time, another
Negro student was pushing his
way through the Courts. Parren
J. Mitchell, a graduate student
in sociology, had applied to the
University in August of 1950.
Mitchell was accepted with the
tacit understanding that he attend
classes in Baltimore--not in Col- legeCollege
Park.
